author: HCAndersen
text: MANY, many years ago lived an emperor, who thought so much of new clothes that he spent all his money in order to obtain them; his only ambition was to be always well dressed.

author: HCAndersen
text: He did not care for his soldiers, and the theatre did not amuse him; the only thing, in fact, he thought anything of was to drive out and show a new suit of clothes.

author: HCAndersen
text: He had a coat for every hour of the day; and as one would say of a king "He is in his cabinet," so one could say of him, "The emperor is in his dressing-room."

author: HCAndersen
text: The great city where he resided was very gay; every day many strangers from all parts of the globe arrived.

author: HCAndersen
text: One day two swindlers came to this city; they made people believe that they were weavers, and declared they could manufacture the finest cloth to be imagined.

author: HCAndersen
text: Their colours and patterns, they said, were not only exceptionally beautiful, but the clothes made of their material possessed the wonderful quality of being invisible to any man who was unfit for his office or unpardonably stupid.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That must be wonderful cloth," thought the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "If I were to be dressed in a suit made of this cloth I should be able to find out which men in my empire were unfit for their places, and I could distinguish the clever from the stupid.

author: HCAndersen
text: I must have this cloth woven for me without delay."

author: HCAndersen
text: And he gave a large sum of money to the swindlers, in advance, that they should set to work without any loss of time.

author: HCAndersen
text: They set up two looms, and pretended to be very hard at work, but they did nothing whatever on the looms.

author: HCAndersen
text: They asked for the finest silk and the most precious gold-cloth; all they got they did away with, and worked at the empty looms till late at night.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I should very much like to know how they are getting on with the cloth," thought the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
text: But he felt rather uneasy when he remembered that he who was not fit for his office could not see it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Personally, he was of opinion that he had nothing to fear, yet he thought it advisable to send somebody else first to see how matters stood.

author: HCAndersen
text: Everybody in the town knew what a remarkable quality the stuff possessed, and all were anxious to see how bad or stupid their neighbours were.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I shall send my honest old minister to the weavers," thought the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "He can judge best how the stuff looks, for he is intelligent, and nobody understands his office better than he."

author: HCAndersen
text: The good old minister went into the room where the swindlers sat before the empty looms.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Heaven preserve us!" he thought, and opened his eyes wide, "I cannot see anything at all," but he did not say so.

author: HCAndersen
text: Both swindlers requested him to come near, and asked him if he did not admire the exquisite pattern and the beautiful colours, pointing to the empty looms.

author: HCAndersen
text: The poor old minister tried his very best, but he could see nothing, for there was nothing to be seen.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh dear," he thought, "can I be so stupid?

author: HCAndersen
text: I should never have thought so, and nobody must know it!

author: HCAndersen
text: Is it possible that I am not fit for my office?

author: HCAndersen
text: No, no, I cannot say that I was unable to see the cloth."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now, have you got nothing to say?" said one of the swindlers, while he pretended to be busily weaving.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, it is very pretty, exceedingly beautiful," replied the old minister looking through his glasses.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a beautiful pattern, what brilliant colours!

author: HCAndersen
text: I shall tell the emperor that I like the cloth very much."

author: HCAndersen
text: "We are pleased to hear that," said the two weavers, and described to him the colours and explained the curious pattern.

author: HCAndersen
text: The old minister listened attentively, that he might relate to the emperor what they said; and so he did.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now the swindlers asked for more money, silk and gold-cloth, which they required for weaving.

author: HCAndersen
text: They kept everything for themselves, and not a thread came near the loom, but they continued, as hitherto, to work at the empty looms.

author: HCAndersen
text: Soon afterwards the emperor sent another honest courtier to the weavers to see how they were getting on, and if the cloth was nearly finished.

author: HCAndersen
text: Like the old minister, he looked and looked but could see nothing, as there was nothing to be seen.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Is it not a beautiful piece of cloth?" asked the two swindlers, showing and explaining the magnificent pattern, which, however, did not exist.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am not stupid," said the man.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is therefore my good appointment for which I am not fit.

author: HCAndersen
text: It is very strange, but I must not let any one know it;" and he praised the cloth, which he did not see, and expressed his joy at the beautiful colours and the fine pattern.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is very excellent," he said to the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
text: Everybody in the whole town talked about the precious cloth.

author: HCAndersen
text: At last the emperor wished to see it himself, while it was still on the loom.

author: HCAndersen
text: With a number of courtiers, including the two who had already been there, he went to the two clever swindlers, who now worked as hard as they could, but without using any thread.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Is it not magnificent?" said the two old statesmen who had been there before.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Your Majesty must admire the colours and the pattern."

author: HCAndersen
text: And then they pointed to the empty looms, for they imagined the others could see the cloth.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What is this?" thought the emperor, "I do not see anything at all.

author: HCAndersen
text: That is terrible!

author: HCAndersen
text: Am I stupid?

author: HCAndersen
text: Am I unfit to be emperor?

author: HCAndersen
text: That would indeed be the most dreadful thing that could happen to me."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Really," he said, turning to the weavers, "your cloth has our most gracious approval;" and nodding contentedly he looked at the empty loom, for he did not like to say that he saw nothing.

author: HCAndersen
text: All his attendants, who were with him, looked and looked, and although they could not see anything more than the others, they said, like the emperor, "It is very beautiful."

author: HCAndersen
text: And all advised him to wear the new magnificent clothes at a great procession which was soon to take place.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is magnificent, beautiful, excellent," one heard them say; everybody seemed to be delighted, and the emperor appointed the two swindlers "Imperial Court weavers."

author: HCAndersen
text: The whole night previous to the day on which the procession was to take place, the swindlers pretended to work, and burned more than sixteen candles.

author: HCAndersen
text: People should see that they were busy to finish the emperor's new suit.

author: HCAndersen
text: They pretended to take the cloth from the loom, and worked about in the air with big scissors, and sewed with needles without thread, and said at last: "The emperor's new suit is ready now."

author: HCAndersen
text: The emperor and all his barons then came to the hall; the swindlers held their arms up as if they held something in their hands and said: "These are the trousers!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "This is the coat!" and "Here is the cloak!" and so on.

author: HCAndersen
text: "They are all as light as a cobweb, and one must feel as if one had nothing at all upon the body; but that is just the beauty of them."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Indeed!" said all the courtiers; but they could not see anything, for there was nothing to be seen.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Does it please your Majesty now to graciously undress," said the swindlers, "that we may assist your Majesty in putting on the new suit before the large looking-glass?"

author: HCAndersen
text: The emperor undressed, and the swindlers pretended to put the new suit upon him, one piece after another; and the emperor looked at himself in the glass from every side.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How well they look!

author: HCAndersen
text: How well they fit!" said all.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What a beautiful pattern!

author: HCAndersen
text: What fine colours!

author: HCAndersen
text: That is a magnificent suit of clothes!"

author: HCAndersen
text: The master of the ceremonies announced that the bearers of the canopy, which was to be carried in the procession, were ready.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am ready," said the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Does not my suit fit me marvellously?"

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he turned once more to the looking-glass, that people should think he admired his garments.

author: HCAndersen
text: The chamberlains, who were to carry the train, stretched their hands to the ground as if they lifted up a train, and pretended to hold something in their hands; they did not like people to know that they could not see anything.

author: HCAndersen
text: The emperor marched in the procession under the beautiful canopy, and all who saw him in the street and out of the windows exclaimed: "Indeed, the emperor's new suit is incomparable!

author: HCAndersen
text: What a long train he has!

author: HCAndersen
text: How well it fits him!"

author: HCAndersen
text: Nobody wished to let others know he saw nothing, for then he would have been unfit for his office or too stupid.

author: HCAndersen
text: Never emperor's clothes were more admired.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But he has nothing on at all," said a little child at last.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Good heavens! listen to the voice of an innocent child," said the father, and one whispered to the other what the child had said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But he has nothing on at all," cried at last the whole people.

author: HCAndersen
text: That made a deep impression upon the emperor, for it seemed to him that they were right; but he thought to himself, "Now I must bear up to the end."

author: HCAndersen
text: And the chamberlains walked with still greater dignity, as if they carried the train which did not exist.
